Package projects.spatial.nodes

Class KDTreeNode

  • java.lang.Object
    • projects.spatial.nodes.KDTreeNode
  • public class KDTreeNode
extends java.lang.Object

    KDTreeNode is an abstraction over nodes of a KD-Tree. It is used extensively by KDTree to implement its functionality.

    YOU ***** MUST ***** IMPLEMENT THIS CLASS!

    See Also:
    KDTree

    • Constructor Detail

      • KDTreeNode

        public KDTreeNode​(KDPoint p)
        1-arg constructor. Stores the provided KDPoint inside the freshly created node.
        Parameters:
        p - The KDPoint to store inside this. Just a reminder: KDPoints are mutable!!!.

    • Method Detail

      • insert

        public void insert​(KDPoint pIn,
                   int currDim,
                   int dims)

        Inserts the provided KDPoint in the tree rooted at this. To select which subtree to recurse to, the KD-Tree acts as a Binary Search Tree on currDim; it will examine the value of the provided KDPoint at currDim and determine whether it is larger than or equal to the contained KDPoint's relevant dimension value. If so, we recurse right, like a regular BST, otherwise left.

        Parameters:
        currDim - The current dimension to consider
        dims - The total number of dimensions that the space considers.
        pIn - The KDPoint to insert into the node.
        See Also:
        delete(KDPoint, int, int)

      • delete

        public KDTreeNode delete​(KDPoint pIn,
                         int currDim,
                         int dims)

        Deletes the provided KDPoint from the tree rooted at this. To select which subtree to recurse to, the KD-Tree acts as a Binary Search Tree on currDim; it will examine the value of the provided KDPoint at currDim and determine whether it is larger than or equal to the contained KDPoint's relevant dimension value. If so, we recurse right, like a regular BST, otherwise left. There exist two special cases of deletion, depending on whether we are deleting a KDPoint from a node who either:

        • Has a NON-null subtree as a right child.
        • Has a NULL subtree as a right child.

        You should consult the class slides, your notes, and the textbook about what you need to do in those two special cases.

        Parameters:
        currDim - The current dimension to consider.
        dims - The total number of dimensions that the space considers.
        pIn - The KDPoint to insert into the node.
        Returns:
        A reference to this after the deletion takes place.
        See Also:
        insert(KDPoint, int, int)

      • search

        public boolean search​(KDPoint pIn,
                      int currDim,
                      int dims)
        Searches the subtree rooted at the current node for the provided KDPoint.
        Parameters:
        pIn - The KDPoint to search for.
        currDim - The current dimension considered.
        dims - The total number of dimensions considered.
        Returns:
        true iff pIn was found in the subtree rooted at this, false otherwise.

      • range

        public void range​(KDPoint anchor,
                  java.util.Collection<KDPoint> results,
                  double range,
                  int currDim,
                  int dims)

        Executes a range query in the given KDTreeNode. Given an "anchor" KDPoint, all KDPoints that have a distance of at most range INCLUSIVE from the anchor point except for the anchor itself should be inserted into the Collection that is passed.

        Remember: range queries behave greedily as we go down (approaching the anchor as "fast" as our currDim allows and prune subtrees that we don't have to visit as we backtrack. Consult all of our resources if you need a reminder of how these should work.

        Parameters:
        anchor - The centroid of the hypersphere that the range query implicitly creates.
        results - A Collection that accumulates all the
        currDim - The current dimension examined by the KDTreeNode.
        dims - The total number of dimensions of our KDPoints.
        range - The INCLUSIVE range from the "anchor" KDPoint, within which all the KDPoints that satisfy our query will fall. The distance metric used} is defined by KDPoint.distance(KDPoint).

      • nearestNeighbor

        public NNData<KDPoint> nearestNeighbor​(KDPoint anchor,
                                       int currDim,
                                       NNData<KDPoint> n,
                                       int dims)

        Executes a nearest neighbor query, which returns the nearest neighbor, in terms of KDPoint.distance(KDPoint), from the "anchor" point.

        Recall that, in the descending phase, a NN query behaves greedily, approaching our "anchor" point as fast as currDim allows. While doing so, it implicitly bounds the acceptable solutions under the current best solution, which is passed as an argument. This approach is known in Computer Science as "branch-and-bound" and it helps us solve an otherwise exponential complexity problem (nearest neighbors) efficiently. Remember that when we want to determine if we need to recurse to a different subtree, it is necessary to compare the distance reported by KDPoint.distance(KDPoint) and coordinate differences! Those are comparable with each other because they are the same data type (Double).

        Parameters:
        anchor - The "ancor" KDPointof the nearest neighbor query.
        currDim - The current dimension considered.
        dims - The total number of dimensions considered.
        n - An object of type NNData, which will define a nearest neighbor as a pair (distance_of_NN_from_anchor, NN), * where NN is the nearest neighbor found.
        Returns:
        An object of type NNData, which exposes the pair (distance_of_NN_from_anchor, NN), where NN is the nearest KDPoint to the anchor KDPoint that we found.
        See Also:
        NNData, kNearestNeighbors(int, KDPoint, BoundedPriorityQueue, int, int)

      • kNearestNeighbors

        public void kNearestNeighbors​(int k,
                              KDPoint anchor,
                              BoundedPriorityQueue<KDPoint> queue,
                              int currDim,
                              int dims)

        Executes a nearest neighbor query, which returns the nearest neighbor, in terms of KDPoint.distance(KDPoint), from the "anchor" point.

        Recall that, in the descending phase, a NN query behaves greedily, approaching our "anchor" point as fast as currDim allows. While doing so, it implicitly bounds the acceptable solutions under the current worst solution, which is maintained as the last element of the provided BoundedPriorityQueue. This is another instance of "branch-and-bound" Remember that when we want to determine if we need to recurse to a different subtree, it is necessary to compare the distance reported by* KDPoint.distance(KDPoint) and coordinate differences! Those are comparable with each other because they are the same data type (Double).

        The main difference of the implementation of this method and the implementation of nearestNeighbor(KDPoint, int, NNData, int) is the necessity of using the class BoundedPriorityQueue effectively. Consult your various resources to understand how you should be using this class.

        Parameters:
        k - The total number of neighbors to retrieve. It is better if this quantity is an odd number, to avoid ties in Binary Classification tasks.
        anchor - The "anchor" KDPoint of the nearest neighbor query.
        currDim - The current dimension considered.
        dims - The total number of dimensions considered.
        queue - A BoundedPriorityQueue that will maintain at most k nearest neighbors of the anchor point at all times, sorted by distance to the point.
        See Also:
        BoundedPriorityQueue

      • height

        public int height()
        + Returns the height of the subtree rooted at the current node. Recall our definition of height for binary trees:
        1. A null tree has a height of -1.
        2. A non-null tree has a height equal to max(height(left_subtree), height(right_subtree)) + 1
        Returns:
        the height of the subtree rooted at the current node.

      • getPoint

        public KDPoint getPoint()
        A simple getter for the KDPoint held by the current node. Remember: KDPoints ARE IMMUTABLE, SO WE NEED TO DO DEEP COPIES!!!
        Returns:
        The KDPoint held inside this.
